qas.question: Who does P. Christiaan Klieger claim to have had a mutual role of religious prelate?

answers.text: the Tibetan lamas and Mongol khans

qas.question: Who does P. Christiaan Klieger believe undertook the former imperial tributaries?

answers.text: the Republic of China and its Communist successors

qas.question: Where does P. Christiaan Klieger work?

answers.text: the California Academy of Sciences in San Francisco

qas.question: Who was the  vice royalty of the Sakya regime established by?
The Sakya regime established what kind of relationship between the Tibetans and Mongol converts?

context: P. Christiaan Klieger, an anthropologist and scholar of <a2_0>the California Academy of Sciences in San Francisco<a2_0/>, writes that the vice royalty of the Sakya regime installed by <a3_0>the Mongols<a3_0/> established a <a4_0>patron and priest relationship<a4_0/> between Tibetans and Mongol converts to Tibetan Buddhism. According to him, <a0_0>the Tibetan lamas and Mongol khans<a0_0/> upheld a "mutual role of religious prelate and secular patron," respectively. He adds that "Although agreements were made between Tibetan leaders and Mongol khans, Ming and Qing emperors, it was <a1_0>the Republic of China and its Communist successors<a1_0/> that assumed the former imperial tributaries and subject states as integral parts of the Chinese nation-state."
